titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Carol Fennelly papers, 1971-1997 MS2153
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-11 11:40:21 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, brochures, videos, films, photographs, newspaper articles, financial records, speeches, and invitations from 1971-1996 relating to the work of homeless rights activist Carol Fennelly and Mitch Snyder as part of the Community for Creative Non-Violence (CCNV).

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Carol Fennelly papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These papers were donated to Gelman Library by Carol Fennelly in 1994.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Carol Fennelly, a long-time activist, is Director of Hope House. For seventeen years Carol lived and worked at the homeless shelters operated by the Community for Creative Non-Violence. In that capacity she was responsible for the creation of numerous new programs within the organization, including a drop-in center for homeless people, a medical infirmary for 30 homeless men, and recruitment and overall coordination of seven separate organizations which provided services in the 1400 bed Federal City Shelter. Carol is the architect of the Districts "cooling centers" which have saved lives by providing cool places for indigent people during extremely hot weather. She is founder and president of the Trust for Affordable Housing which built over 350 units of Single Room Occupancy Housing for single homeless people in the District of Columbia. In addition, her reputation as an outspoken and effective advocate on issues of concern to homeless people is well known. Along with Mitch Snyder she designed campaigns which won voting rights for homeless people; won passage of the Stewart B. McKinney bill; won passage of the D.C. Right to Overnight Shelter Act; brought a quarter million people to Washington for the Housing Now! March in 1989; and acquired the old Federal City College along with $13 million in renovation funds to create a model shelter in the nation's capitol. She founded Hope House after spending almost a year writing about the plight of families torn apart by the closure of Lorton Prison.
this history came from the Hope House website. http://www.hopehousedc.org/about/about-us.htm

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, brochures, videos, films, photographs, newspaper articles, financial records, speeches, and invitations. This material covers the years 1971-96. This material relates to the work of homeless rights activist Carol Fennelly and Mitch Snyder as part of the Community for Creative Non-Violence (CCNV). CCNV began in the early 1970s as an anti-war group and evolved into an organization that provides food, clothing, shelter, and educational programs for the poor and homeless. Snyder and Fennelly employed non-violent confrontational protest tactics aimed at shocking the public and drawing media attention to the cause of homelessness. A portion of these papers relate to the organizations Housing Now and the Trust for Affordable Housing and the work done on behalf of homeless residents of Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into fourteen series: Correspondence, Demonstrations, Ephemera, Entertainment, Financial records, Graphics, Housing, Newspaper articles, Publicity and publications, Speaking engagements, Speeches, Subject files, Video and audio materials, and Oversize materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence. The material dates from 1971-93. This material relates to the work of activist Carol Fennelly primarily related to the issue of the homeless in America. Some of these letters were written by Mitch Snyder during his time in Danbury State Prison from 1971-72.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains leaflets, brochures, articles, permit requests, and other publicity materials dated from 1975-93. This material relates to various demonstrations and marches undertaken by Carol Fennelly, Mitch Snyder and the Community for Creative Non-violence. The issues relate to the issue of the homeless.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains one set of clothing worn by Martin Sheen during the making of the movie "Samaritan" about the life and work of Mitch Snyder. The other items in this series are plaques related to the work of Mitch Snyder.

did.unittitle: Clothing worn by Martin Sheen during making of the movie "Samaritan" about the life and work of Mitch Snyder
Plaques and awards for Mitch Snyder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains scripts, television show documents, and movie premiere documents. This material mostly relates to the production of the movie "Samaritan" about the life of Mitch Snyder. There is also material related to a 60 Minutes television episode from 1993 and other television projects. This material is dated from 1984-93.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains financial records related to the Community for Creative Non-Violence including budgets and fundraising. This material covers the years 1988-93.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains bills, articles, campaign literature, correspondence, financial records, agendas and meeting minutes, and press releases. This material dates from 1984-97. Much of this material relates to work of the group the Trust for Affordable Housing and the operation and renovation of the homeless shelter at 425 2nd St.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains newspaper articles relate to the work of Carol Fennelly and the Community for Creative Non-Violence. The articles date from 1974-93.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains brochures, press releases, flyers, articles, a calendar papers, reports, manuals, and manuscripts. The materials date from 1979-87. The materials cover the topics of homeless shelters, the movie "Samaritan", and hunger in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains invitations and other materials related to the speaking engagements of Mitch Snyder. These documents date from 1986-90. These materials are primarily from universities, public libraries, and community groups.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains speeches written and presented by Mitch Snyder. These speeches date from 1985-89. Many are note dated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains among many document types items related to census materials, biographical data, and statements. These materials date from 1977-93. This series is composed of materials collected and created by the Mitch Snyder, Carol Fennelly and the Community for Creative Non-Violence during the work performed on behalf of homeless people in Washington, D.C. and other activist causes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains videos, audio cassettes, and audio reel to reel tapes documenting the work of Carol Fennelly, Mitch Snyder, and the Community for Creative Non-Violence. These items date from 1984-93. The topics include homeless people, housing, and shelters.
